subject: Business
title: The Mere Exposure Effect
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Mere Exposure Effect usable.

hook.text: You hear a song you hate. After 20 plays, you're humming it. Familiarity breeds preference, not contempt.

buildup.text: The mere exposure effect: the more we encounter something, the more we tend to like it.

discovery.text: This is why brands repeat logos, jingles, and slogans relentlessly. Each exposure builds unconscious preference.

twist.text: Too much exposure causes wear-out. There's a sweet spot between familiarity and annoyance.

climax.text: Coca-Cola spends $4 billion annually on advertising despite 96% global brand recognition. Exposure must never stop.

punchline.text: They don't need to know they like you. They just need to recognize you.

quiz.question: What is the mere exposure effect?
options: Repeated exposure to something increases our preference for it
First impressions are the only ones that matter
People always prefer new and unfamiliar brands
